sentence: Our studies are not only the first to investigate the link between dark traits and epistemic beliefs, but also to propose a model taking into account the complex interactions between dark traits, epistemic beliefs and political orientation as well as their collective effect on COVID‐19–related cognitions and behavior (for an overview, see Figure 1).

Our studies are not only the first to investigate the link between dark traits and epistemic beliefs, but also to propose a model taking into account the complex interactions between dark traits, epistemic beliefs and political orientation as well as their collective effect on COVID‐19–related cognitions and behavior (for an overview, see Figure 1).

Our studies are not only the first to investigate the link between dark traits and epistemic beliefs, but also to propose a model taking into account the complex interactions between dark traits, epistemic beliefs and political orientation as well as their collective effect on COVID‐19–related cognitions and behavior (for an overview, see Figure 1).
The path coefficients, standard errors, and p‐values are shown in Figure 2a.
Furthermore, Faith in Intuition for Facts and Need for Evidence predicted COVID‐19 protective behavior (Figure 2b).

Importantly, we found a significant overall interaction effect of political orientation: The positive association between D and the endorsement of COVID‐19 conspiracy theories increased with a more right‐wing political orientation, B = .12; SEB = .05, 95%CI [.02; .23], p = .024 (see Figure 3a).
We also found a moderating effect of political orientation on the effect of D on COVID‐19 protective behavior, B = −.10, SEB = .05, 95%CI [−.19; −.01], p = .033 (Figure 3b).
Path coefficients, standard errors, and p‐values are shown in Figure 4.
As expected, Need for Evidence and Truth is Political predicted COVID‐19 protective behavior (Figure 4b).
Path coefficients, standard errors, and p‐values are shown in Figure 5.
Furthermore, Need for Evidence and Truth is Political predicted COVID‐19 protective behavior in the expected directions (Figure 5b).
